commentBody: Read this one Lima Charlie.
Very nice.
This puzzle was missing a K and an M, but was so close to being a pangram! With ATOZ as fill and the NATO alphabet as the theme, can’t help but think that was a missed opportunity.
November oscar tango oscar oscar bravo alfa bravo.
First letter of NATO alphabet is generally rendered as "Alfa." Not sure why...

Finally got my mojo back after the last two days VEXed me - bonus as that was my final clue :)

Enjoyed this theme!

OK, ready?

The Budweiser icon woke everyone else up groaning about leg pain.
Goldilocks tried branching out to other mammalian genera.
The Spaghetti western may have originated in Western Africa?
There were enough Astor Piazzolla pieces to play for the lengthy dance contest.
The exclusive clubhouse prided itself on its cold soup.
Single malt, with grape flavoring. Yum.
Oh dear, is Ecuador now part of the U.S. along with Canada?
That guy was the absolute GOAT in tennis.
Couple of November alpha tango igloo Charlie kilo sierra in this one
The southeast part of the puzzle was brutal IMO. Too many obscure proper names and acronyms. TAUTEN is also a stretch (pun intended)
COTTA/HIYA, I had COTTo/HIYo. Would that not be a valid solution to both clues?

Um—aren’t the puzzles supposed to get harder through the week, not easier? I thought this was easier than yesterday, which was easier than Tuesday.
Look, I have nothing against this puzzle, per se, just it would be a perfectly fine  Tuesday or Wednesday. Nothing tricky about the theme or most of the clues.

Everyone who has ever had to work with the NATO alphabet has a story about how they can’t live without it.  It’s burned into our memory banks. 

So, I’d love to hear your stories about how the NATO alphabet was horrendously massacred at your work. 

At a former job, they tried to move away from the NATO alphabet after a telecommunications system’s merge for PSAP services. 

One deputy asked for a name to be run with “z as in xylophone.”

There were a few Kinks in this puzzle. Two to be exact: Ray and Dave DAVIES. The constructor really got me going, really got me, with the NATO alphabet theme, which I enjoyed, especially golf course for GAZPACHO. At first I thought this was going to be one that I filled in with answers that seemed to make no sense, but I actually figured out the trick before seeing the revealer.  There was more filler than I would like, but on balance, more fun than not.
I really liked this puzzle, and yet, a panda is not a bear.

Our columnist writes:
"The phonetic NATO alphabet, originally developed to clarify communication during World War II..."

Elie,
The NATO alphabet was adopted in 1956 (as Sam notes in the article for which you provided the link), well after WWII. Phonetic alphabets were already in use in WWI.
Ice rain... not a thing. It's freezing rain.
Liked it. Enough clues became logical /after/ a word was solved, that I thought it was on a Thursday plane.  SNOW DAY AGAIN, THURSDAY!  Unlike Christmas, snow time like the present.
Got the Watusi clue thanks to the Cher movie Burlesque

Thank god for Patti Smith. Otherwise I wouldn't have known Wakiki from Watusi. And thank god for Patti Smith anyway, for the whole shebang. https://youtube.com/watch?v=cSk6jfln84A Lyrics for "Land of a Thousand Dances" ... Do you know how to pony like Bony Maroney? Do you know how to twist? Well it goes like this, it goes like this Baby mash potato Do the alligator, do the alligator And you twist the twister like your baby sister I want your baby sister, give me your baby sister, I dig your baby sister And rise up on her knees Do the sweet pea, do the sweet pee-pee Roll down on her back Got to lose control, got to lose control Got to lose control and then you take control Then you're rolled down on your back And you like it like that, like it like that, like it like that, like it like that And then you do the Watusi, yeah do the Watusi *** And what is the Watusi? Possibly appropriated from traditional African Tutsi dances, as seen in "King Solomon's Mines" (1950) -- taken from an H. Rider Haggard adventure novel of African conquest published in the 1880s. https://youtube.com/watch?v=j3RTcIE_F0k And this might have inspired the Orions' "Wah-Watusi," a hit that was covered by Chubby Checkers, Smoky Robinson and many others and was one of the soundtracks to the dance. Finally, here's LBJ's daughter Luci Baines Johnson dancing the Watusi in 1964: https://youtube.com/watch?v=L8r-tAM54H0 Um, yeah.
“Alpha” is not part of the NATO alphabet; “alfa” is the code for A. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) does use “alpha”, which made 38D pretty confusing for me.

Flyspecking brought me in 7 minutes (!) over my Thursday average, but you all KNOW that 59A was not my problem!

P as in ptomaine, E as in euchre...

Not my favorite puzzle.  As several commenters point out, some of the clues/answers were a little off, and the 'trick" (simply that the answers started with a certain letter indicated in NATO code at the beginning of the clue) didn't seem clever enough for a typical Thursday.

David, the constructor, asks “What else was TANGO going to be?”

Perhaps “Tango lesson”…

TEACHING

Teaching, noun: something taught… as in a lesson.

Fits the symmetry too, yes?

Pretty darned fast for a Thursday.  Theme was okay.

I still think Tuesday was harder, better, and more fun.

{ shrug emoji }

Somebody made a joke about expecting an easy Thursday in this bizarro week.  Guess it wasn't a joke.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler
Bleh. This needed more time on the drawing board.
I've been really enjoying the last few puzzles! They do seem noticeably harder than I'm used to for early-mid week, but that's not a bad thing.

The Tuesday puzzle was a walk in the park compared to this one.

The puzzle is filled and looks terrific. I don't quite know what I did, but I did it, and I liked doing it.  My first run through netted nothing, so I went back and started putting in fills I thought might be right, along with some that I knew had to be right, and the whole thing slowly started to right itself.  

There will be those who say how easy they thought it was—CLYDESDALE? Really? (or SRSLY? to be au courant), and some who think it was just off, but as I said, I liked it.

FEAR not, David Wiliams, we will welcome your next construction. ALL IN ALL, this one was a winner.
I've waited all this week for a puzzle like this. Renews my faith.
Surprised at how many thought this was easy. I found it to be incredibly frustrating. Even though I am familiar with the NATO alphabet.

I gave up toward the end. I do this for fun (?!) so finally figured out how to turn the timer off. Timers are never fun. Then tried to remember how I started doing these in the first place. 2010 or so. The NYT delivered every morning around 5. In a plastic bag if it was raining, otherwise just a rubber band. The smell of the ink on newsprint as I started with the important part of the paper (the puzzle), folding the section in half and then in half again while I poured the coffee. Mechanical pencil out, wondering how far I’d get in the allotted 15 minutes I had with it before I had to start getting serious about the day. On an occasional Monday or Tuesday I’d get it done. Otherwise it would still be waiting on the dining room table for after work. 

Life was better when


That unsaid, I really liked the theme here, even if I didn’t finish the puzzle. And I would have then, too.

Count me among the solvers who found Tuesday, Wednesday, and today’s all harder than usual. Still fun! They just seem to have more tricky clueing and/or less immediately recognizable names than I’m used to.

For some reason we think the NATO alphabet is hilarious in our house and use it to spell things just to be silly so I especially like this puzzle. Putting polar instead of panda slowed me down. 

My quibble in recent puzzles—using full names without any clever warning or indication. Seems to defy convention. I will adjust if I must :)

BRAVO! Fun theme. I didn’t realize that VEX could mean “bring trouble to.” I thought it meant to make angry. For a long time I had it as HEX, thinking EHAN was a writer I was unfamiliar with. Also I’m terrible at French but ATOI means “yours”? I thought that was votre, but what do I know? Kinks on Midnight Special: https://youtu.be/yxgut9pmopU
Some of us never served in the military.  What little we know about the NATO alphabet comes from police dramas.  Didn’t like this puzzle at all.

WELCHS is a soda?
GAZPACHO = course? I get it but...
SERGIO Leone had to google.

I like a tricky Thursday and I enjoy NATO alphabet puzzles but this theme seemed to be stretched a bit far. 

Hope we get a good Friday puzzle for the impending Nashville snowstorm (3 to 5 I inches! Might as well be a blizzard ❄️)

So many proper names crossing one another (ARSENE/EVAN, JJWATT, SERGIO and OLSEN/SELENA, DAVIES/EUNICE, ARTHURASHE) and many that I wasn't familiar with that this one involved a lot of tedious flyspecking for me. Otherwise I thought the theme was fun.

How many proper names were there? Twenty? More? It sure felt like it was a lot. I sort of got the theme (NATO alphabet was a gimme, and the themed entries were witty, I guess), but with how many lookups I needed to deal with the trivia-heavy fill I did not enjoy this puzzle at all.

Also, ATOZ? I see now that it should be parsed A TO Z, but that was just not gettable for me as I was solving, especially with the (for me) unusual cross of TAUTEN (I know it's a valid word but not one I've encountered often enough to come up with it today, having trouble with _TOZ and never knowing whether DoH or DUH will be the answer to 'Obviously!')

I needed to check the puzzle for the first time in weeks...
Did not enjoy. Weird cluing, clunky fill. No one calls it "ice rain." It's freezing rain.
I should be able to solve the puzzle without knowing Italian and French…. Or having to look online for the answers….
Crossing two Italian words (TUTTO and COTTA) seems like a bad idea in an English crossword.

A sort of fun, sort of annoying crossword. Great theme but too many proper names. Solved nearly the entire puzzle but got stuck in the weird and unseemly convergence of highbrow and lowbrow stuff in the NE corner. It turns out I was vaguely familiar with all but one of the answers. I needed one look up - Lisa Ling - then the rest came to me. So a fun puzzle overall but lacking some thoughtfulness with the crosses.

Clever puzzle. Putting the theme clues in italics made it much easier.  

I agree with others regarding ICERAIN. It's called freezing rain, and believe me, it's more than just a driving hazard (anyone else remember the 1998 ice storm?)

Polar instead of PANDA slowed things up for me in the NE corner
I'm just going to pretend this puzzle never happened and look ahead to Friday.
I liked it, especially the subtly clever clue [Long, long time]. AEON is not just an "alternate spelling" of eon, but a longer spelling. It is not just a very long time.

The Watusi is mentioned at some 6 minutes into the Beatles music concrete tape loop exercise Revolution 9.  I know this because it came up randomly on my ancient iPad the other day.  For some reason I was too lazy to push the next button and listened to the whole thing.

Thankfully, it was not followed immediately by Steve Reich's Its Gonna Rain which is also on that iPod.

Yikes to that NE corner. A few unfamiliar names + an unknown quote= several puzzle checks and a blue star for me. If you don’t know, you don’t know. 

On the plus side, the theme was as easy as Alfa Bravo Charlie to decipher. But that’s not necessarily a plus. Ultimately, this puzzle was challenging for me, just not in the right way. I think I deserve a whiskey. (And a tango, if anyone’s up for it.)

Interesting theme but the rest ? Meh. Too many proper names you either know or you don't. Having obscure clues cross, just tedious.

I had hoped with Will Shorts returning this sort of editing would cease. It isn't clever to just be obscure.
Thanks David! 40A my favourite AND I had just had a bowl.

EhAN Goldberg? Sure, why not? 20th and 21st c. parents have prided themselves on giving their children unintuitive names. 

Because to hEX someone is to truly bring trouble to them.

I echo Shrike but just say let's pretend this whole week never happened. As a reasonably good M-Th solver (yeah, I sometimes Check Answers and use some other little helps to keep it enjoyable), Monday, which is usually breezy fun - wasn't. I even had to Check it and going back years I can't find the last time I did that for *Monday.* And quite a big crowd agreed Tuesday should have been Wednesday. And Wed, eh.Seems a lot of people aren't happy with Th either - and while a few trivia questions are fun and enlightening, I agree too many is just frustrating (yeah yeah define "too many"... but whatever it is seems this puzzle had "tm."  When I started Monday, I wondered if it was just me - but then saw the general tone and realizef it wasn't. I'd really encourage the editors to go back to the levels and progressions you had before ( and yes, as another clever puzzler noted, we know bc thanks to you NYT we have our averages over time - and M and Tu were definitely outliers.
Whiskey Tango Foxtrot.  😉 Great fun.

Somehow I managed to gold-star this one without any look-ups or hints (which for myself I would consider cheats)— but I sat seemingly forever trying to unlock that NE corner with little hope of success. Only my stubbornness prevented me from throwing in the towel; I think I might have spent 3x what I spent on the entire rest of the grid getting nowhere there. In retrospect, I recognize that I got in my own way, but still: it did seem needlessly natick-y! I had no hope of getting an NFL player from ten years ago without serious help from the crosses, especially when I was thinking of only a last name rather than two initials. And even acknowledging early on that  the “knight” might have a lower-case “k”, I managed to take a ridiculously long time to twig to JEDI. 🙄 LISA Ling should have come easily, but paradoxically she was TOO familiar: I had convinced myself that this was a newer name that I didn’t know and would have to guess at. D’oh! (I still don’t understand the Shelley quote, which I had never heard before. Wouldn’t Hope expect finite woes? 🤔)

Even owning my ignorance & obtuseness, I think most of the objections posed by other commenters here have validity. Over one third of the entries were proper nouns— which seems excessive. Most were well-known to me—but I pity the non-American solvers! Also, I would love to see a citation for ICE RAIN. “Freezing rain”, “sleet”, or “icy rain”— okay, but ICE RAIN?

This one, IMO, has some serious issues.

Have to say I  wasn't "wowed" by this one. The theme was pretty basic compared to many ingenious others I've seen on a Thursday ("So it's a number beginning with T, fine... It's city beginning with Q, fine...."). 
And I definitely agree with others that the ambiguous COTTO/COTTA and HIYO/HIYA combination should have been weeded out in the editing process - very dodgy there indeed.
Still, good for a quick mental distraction (above average time for me today though!) - much appreciated as always.

A mixed bag for me, which perhaps makes it a good Thursday. Started well, without understanding the theme. A proper headslap when I got NATO.  DUH!

I’m pleased as punch to get WATUSI. I’ve been bingeing Swing dancing on YouTube for a while, the incredible dancers have introduced me to the moves for that, plus the Nitty Gritty amongst others. 

Ray’s surname was a gimme, but the other names were complete unknowns, making that whole right side almost impossible to fill.
Is 42A a soda brand? 

I’m on a bit of a high this morning as we won the pub quiz last night. A very rare event which of course necessitated extra drinks. Probably why my eyes are struggling to focus on the puzzle. That’s the excuse I’m sticking to anyway.
I really enjoyed the “aha” moment that this puzzle gave me!

Caught onto the theme pretty quick, but thought for sure I would be naticked out of a gold star on this one. I’m honestly amazed I was able to get this one to the finish line. Felt like I was totally flailing at the end. But taking pot shots at random naticks worked for me this time
Took a while to replace the ICAO alphabet with NATO. The italics helped me correct the misspelling of Alfa. Finished with the COTTO/HIYO solution.

Finished it without look ups. Can't say I enjoyed it. 

Names and trivia and names and quotes and names and a theme that was ... meh. This one just didn't tickle my fancy.

I caught on to the NATO alphabet theme early on but forgot (no italics in my printed copy) by the time I got to QUITO.  As I wrote in that answer, I just shrugged and figured there must be a QUITO in Quebec as well as in Ecuador.  38D made me count them and find the 8th.

I liked the meta THIRTEEN at 27A and [Mystery writer, in brief] for ANON.

I liked the theme here, I cottoned onto NATO pretty fast but didn’t understand the theme clues straight away.
 I needed some Wordplays help like I always do on Thursdays, but I didn’t love how the theme was given away in the Tricky Clues section. Usually I like to get those tricky clues out of the way to then make my attempt at the theme. Today it was sort of spoiled for me

My company in Vietnam was known as 'hard-luck alpha' since we were always in the wrong place at the wrong time. But... we're all still in touch on a face-book group - even our former company commander. So, in the long run... Anyway - you'd think this would be right up my alley, and a lot of it fell together fairly smoothly once I caught on, but still had to cheat in a couple of places to finish it. And... BODHITREE? Can someone explain that? And... of course an appropriate puzzle find today. A Sunday form March 24, 2019 by Trenton Charlson with the title "Code Switching." The 'reveal' in that was a pair of answers; NATO PHONETICALPHABET And some theme answers: BOSTONTANGOPARTY YANKEEBOTHER UNIFORMBET THEPRINCESSANDTHEPAPA BRAVOSTING CHARLIEWORLD Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/24/2019&g=22&d=A I'll shut up now. ...

Even understanding the trick halfway through the puzzle didn't make it easier. Some, like the Clydesdale horse and Welch's soda, were simply unknown to me, and cluing Ashe with just "male" is extremely generic. Oh, and pOLAR has the same number of letters as PANDA. The trick in itself was neat, but either those clues or the rest of the answers should have been easier to strike a balance imo.

Why is there so many theme clues discussed in the “tricky clues” section? 

I usually check that first if I get stuck, hoping that solving some of the clues will help me figure out the theme. Unfortunately, today I had it spoilt to me. :(

Can’t be the only one that thought
it was a pangram and went back looking 
for a k and an m..?

Really had fun with this one!

I’ve never memorized the NATO alphabet,
which is odd, now that I think about it.

I memorize everything!
And I’m horribly, terribly, embarrassingly bad
at spelling things out 
on the phone.

Me- That’s Jones, j, o, n, e, s.

Person on phone - How do you spell that?

Me (panicking) - Okay, uh, J as in…jumprope…
O as in…Ottawa…
N… as in…next-of-kin…
E, like in… epiphany…?
and S like…uh…slippery..?

Person - What?

Me- *hangs up*

Got through it but I can't say I liked it.
Too many names but they were gettable with the crosses.
I thought we had moved on from naticks
I LIMA OSCAR VICTOR ECHO using the NATO alphabet.  I struggle with intersecting proper nouns.  WHISKY TANGO HOTEL.

I found this to be a serviceable puzzle, but that's not what I expect on Thursday.  It seemed rather lackluster, and once I saw the author's credentials in the column (i.e. that he was the one who constructed the five "Blackbird" puzzles), I wasn't surprised.  I can't get into that set of puzzles, and have no idea so far why I should be interested in that poem.  At least I didn't come into this one with those preconceived notions, since I didn't realize who the constructor was.  

In other words, I didn't find much excitement in this one on its own merits.

Two inelegant things were that "alpha" in the 51A clue is not the spelling used in the NATO alphabet, and "Charlie" used in the 17A clue, although it is the NATO spelling, is not the usual spelling in the phrase "Charley horse".  

And WELCH'S as a soda brand?  Technically correct and admissable, but très niche.
Anyone else misguided by their spelling bee expertise with TUTTi at 27D?  I corrected it with the aha moment of the soup course GAZPACHO.

Oh, my brain was on high alert before entering the first square.  The constructor’s name rang a bell, I looked him up, and oh yeah, he’s the guy with those identical-grid “looking at a blackbird” Saturday puzzles that gave my brain a Crossfit-grade workout.

So, I’m not surprised that the box held many riddles for me today.  Names I didn’t know, deeply-submerged-in-memory words that took a while to pry out, and actual riddles, such as the sensational [Mystery writer, in brief?] for ANON.

Story of my solve: Vague mass of hardly anything, steeped in slowness, leading to islets of fill-in, morphing into blobs, crescendoing into a mad dash to the finish, with a highly-satisfied brain.  Figuring out the theme, with a resounding aha, was the catalyst.

This grid is so well filled. What a high-quality answer set with hardly a whiff of junk and a wide variety of fields represented.   Look at that gorgeous filled in grid! I thought the cluing was high quality as well, with the Thursday-right level of vagueness and sparks of wit.

David P., you can make a capital-C crossword, and I savored what you made today.  Thank you so much for this!

I solved the NFL one using the CROSSWORD alphabet: Jail Jedi Woes Panda Phat Thirteen The puzzle held my hand like that a lot today, but in the end, not such a struggle. Seemed a bit throw-back-ish and random. “Toss to”? You mean so I can paint it green? Today’s little mystery: what caused such a moment for “ersatz” around 1940? https://tinyurl.com/4zamb7uz

You either know it or don’t. Good idea for the theme, caught on to NATO quickly, but the rest…meh. I like puzzles that are solvable through skill. The crosses were not helpful at all. Most answers just seemed cherry picked for the sake of obscurity. Not for me today. Hoping I’m on a similar wavelength with the next creator tomorrow.

feeling validated by all these comments agreeing it was weirdly hard but not in a satisfying way. i straight up had to look at the answer key to finish the SW corner and i've never done that before 😭 lol. like other comments pointed out -- too heavy on the proper nouns. i did enjoy the theme though!

I enjoyed this. But GAZPACHO?  Charlie horse is the name of a horse that begins with C.  Whiskey soda is a soda that begins with W.  Golf course is a course that begins with G.  Soup course?  Salad course?  I’ve never heard of a gazpacho course.  Did Marjorie Taylor Green write this puzzle?
Thanks for all the commiserations for the non US solvers. I found out that Welch's is sold in the UK but it is called grape juice, not soda. Not that I knew it! But hello BBC.

Sierra Tango Romeo Alpha November Delta Sierra Thread. 

Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #312
“Off the hook!”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

Out constructor today is Joanne Song but it must be tough when searches for your name are dominated by Lady Gaga.
What was that all about?

Really disliked this one (although I solved without lookups). Chock full with proper names that I don’t care about, indeterminate foreign words, etc. DAVIES crossing WATUSI and COTTA (which could equally well have been COTTO) crossing HIYA (not a word)? Give me a break.

Even for the glue (of which there was plenty!) the cluing was subpar. An ALP is a [Challenge for a skier]? In what sense other than it’s a mountain? What else would one ski on? I’ve skied in the Alps and there are plenty of easy trails to choose from. How did that clue make it past the editors? It’s not even cute: it’s just wrong. 

A sparkling theme would have made up for the decidedly mediocre fill. But the execution was poor. ARTHUR ASHE is indeed a male, yes. But that hardly seems his defining characteristic. Similarly, one can serve GAZPACHO as a first course, but that’s true of many many foods.

I understand that a clue is not a definition. But these are really terrible clues IMO. It was basically a thematic equivalent of green paint. The other themers were better (I admit that I cracked a smile at SERGIO) but not enough to make up for the stinkers. 

I have enjoyed being perplexed by David’s enigmatic homage to Wallace Stevens. Let’s hope he goes back to that soon.
Longtime SUV?  It was out of production from MYs '96-'21.  Maybe longtime technically (longtime doesn't mean continuous), but still.

This one defeated me. In fact, I had two squares wrong when I first finished. Can't remember the last time that happened. Both mistakes involved names, of which there were an *awful* lot today. And both errors were my fault, and could have been avoided with some reflection. But I simply wanted to be done with this one, which I found one of the least enjoyable (especially on a Thursday!) puzzles in a long while.

I had HEX rather than VEX, and failed to notice that EVAN made more sense than EHAN. But I didn't know the director, and was also unsure of the N since I didn't know the thief's name either. I also had JTWATT, since I didn't know the football star, and I was misdirected (nice job there) into thinking Knight was yet another proper name.

About the puzzle---no idea why this is running today. This seems a Wednesday puzzle. The theme was simple enough, and seemed to involve no Thursday trickery.

Some of the fill was ... well, pick your own adjectives for TAUTEN, ISON and ... ICERAIN (no such thing).

For the constructor's and editor's sakes, I sure hope other folks enjoyed this one more than I did. No way on Earth I'd have run this puzzle, no matter what day of the week.

This puzzle would have been much tougher had I not thought to look at the newspaper version and thus espied the italicization of the clues. No italics in the ordinary pdf.

Golf course and whiskey soda were the biggest stretches, IMO.

Still respectably chewy.
Enjoyed it, thanks David.

Fun puzzle, breezy solve in 2/3 my average time. Tumbled the theme after Sierra Leone but got hung up in NE by going with “polar” instead of PANDA and knowing neither the 10D or 13D names. Gotta agree with others, though — GAZPACHO was a real stretch.

Liked the NATO alphabet clueing. Very clever.

Sadly, I hated everything else. Needed a lie down afterwards.
I always have trouble with the obsolete terms. Yesterday it was 'orale', today 'Nato'.
My lack of Italian did me in.
I found the theme easy today, but to complete the puzzle I had to resort to several lookups due to all the non-English and name crosses. Not fun.

I enjoyed this one. Felt like a breezy Thursday with an unusual theme, something new. Loved the THIRTEEN connection and NODTO LUPIN. TAUTEN was bizarre, but I love the sound of it…might have to start randomly dropping it into conversations.

I thought it might have been just me, but I can see by the comments this was a rough one.  I don't mind working for it, but the crossings were tough and/or weirdly clued.  I love a clever clue as much as the next person, but please give us a toehold somewhere.

NO REBUS!

That was a PSA for those who don't enjoy rebuses on Thursday... personally I love them! 😄

The theme was fairly straightforward, but I found many of the clues and answers to be tricky enough for any Thursday. I got stuck in several spots but managed to muddle through to a gold star.

Reading the constructor's notes was good for a laugh, if you are familiar with his series of puzzles "Thirteen Ways..."

Well, usual non-US woes with proper names, compensated to some extent by being fine with stuff like GAZPACHO (which is often served as a intermediate course), the Italian words, and the WATUSI.
Not sure an ALP is a challenge for a skier, unlesss we're talking ski mountaineering, and found "Dressed to the NINES" hilarious---in Scotland it means that you're ludicrously overdressed, the antithesis of style.

Ugh! Two puzzles this week that I did not enjoy and all of them were over my average time. The theme didn’t seem consistent as others have pointed out. There were also so many obscure names and just stuff I did not know. Chalking it up to a learning opportunity but I can’t say I’m looking forward to the end-of-week puzzles. 

Emus … help!

WELCH'S makes grape juice, not soda.

Fun fact: Welch's grape juice was created in response to the Methodist church's insistence that communion be taken not with wine but the "pure juice of the grape."

This was quite the brain-twister!  Fortunately for me, I started with 30D.  (I'm not really DRESSED TO THE NINES--I have on LLBean flannel Jammies) but I quickly had a trio of entries that led me farther South....  and suddenly, ARTHUR ASHE stood before me.  

Alas, TUTTI didn't work with GAZPACHO, so I tried TANTO for 27D, then revised for BUOYS at the crossing.  I didn't go back to reconsider, so I have an incorrect letter! Waaah.  Does  this make me an ERSATZ Solver?

We enjoyed the (impossible but endearing) Lupin series.
Less enjoyable:  JJWATT (Who? What? Was this trip necessary?)
Neither have I heard of the DAVIES, who are, it seems, Kinky.  Ha.

I have never heard of a WELCH'S soda (soft drink, pop, carbonated beverage)...it sounds like a tummy-ache waiting to happen.  Well, enough about my life of deprivation (vehicles, sports, junk food in plastic containers.)  Enlightenment is hard to come by!
Nice Thursday puzzle! Can't think that any NYT puzzle solver doesn't know about the NATO alphabet, as there are frequent NATO alphabet clues every year!
An incredible amount of gobbledygook and extremely clunky cluing / fill in this one.  Major yikes - needed to go back to the drawing board.

I'm one of those for whom this was not a letter-perfect theme. I liked a lot of it, particularly the fill, but much of theme felt inelegant: I mean, [Charlie horse] was neat, and [Papa bear] had the ambiguity of being either PANDA or POLAR; but gazpacho doesn't constitute a (soup) course, rather an element of one. And [Alpha male] could have been Alan Arkin, Ansel Adams, or even Alan Alexander Milne--why a tennis player, and not a photographer, actor, or author? (Hey--those last two begin with "a"!). And I didn't realize that the official spelling was "alfa," but learning it made it feel even more . . . wait, doesn't Juliette drive an Alfa Romeo? But, to my mind, the most inelegant was [Quebec]/QUITO--I mean, they're both cities. Which made me think . . . I am not widely traveled--I've never been to Polynesia, for instance--but I have been to both Québec and Quito, and I can tell you they're nothing alike. On the other hand, my first thought on visiting Cuenca, Ecuador's *third* largest city, was how much it reminded me of Québec: both colonial cities built around a tight, walled core. But the puzzle did make me think of how often the Nato alphabet shows up in indie (not india) rock music: long before Wilco released Yankee Hotel Foxtrot, Bloodhound Gang sang this: https://youtube.com/watch?v=JZpxaiNV_sM (def. NSFW). How do I know these things? Luckily I can get that sound out of my ear with a simple ligature: https://youtube.com/watch?v=L2X3JP8aINo Or not . . .

Interesting phenomenon re: ICE RAN that I just noticed. 

Like many others, I had never head freezing RAIN referred to as ICE RAIN. So I looked it up. 

Unlike many others, I don't automatically ASSume that if *I* have not previously seen a particular usage/word/definition, that it MUST, therefore be WRONG WRONG WRONG! I usually check to see if it's a regionalism that I was not aware of, or a word that was not in my lexicon, and so on -- I try to find an opportunity to learn something. I don't get angry at the puzzle. 

So I fired up the electric google machine and entered, in quotes, "ICE RAIN". Right at the top was a definition for ICE RAIN at Dictionary.com. I don't usually use that as a source, and the results here might illustrate why. 

Dictionary.com defines ICE RAIN as freezing RAIN. A synonym. But if you check out the example sentences, they are all - every one - like this: 

"Forecasters expect the storm system to hobble the upper Midwest with ice, rain and snow for days, as well as move into the Northeast and central Appalachians."

Dictionary.com is based upon Random House Unabridged Dictionary, with borrowings from several others, including American Heritage. The only dictionary listed that I own in hard copy is an old (third edition, ©1996) AH Unabridged dictionary, and it lacks an entry for ICE RAIN. 

I conclude that Dictionary.com scrapes online sources for entries and is befuddled when a comma comes between two words. 

I concur that the answer is dicey.

@Grant Well yes . . . from wikipedia: "According to the Government of Canada, the Government of Quebec, and the Geographical Names Board of Canada, the names of Canadian cities and towns have only one official form. Thus, Québec is officially spelled with an accented é in both Canadian English and French. However, province names can have different forms in English and French. As a result, in English, the federal government style distinguishes the city and province by spelling the city with an acute accent (Québec) and the province without one (Quebec). The government of Quebec spells both names "Québec", including when writing in English. In French, the two are distinguished in that province names including Quebec generally take definite articles, while city names do not. As a result, the city is Québec and the province is le Québec; "in Quebec City" is à Québec and "in the province of Quebec" is au Québec; and so forth." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quebec_City#Name_and_usage But one should note that the city's official logo says "Ville de Québec."
